title: Between 4 October 2019 and 1 April 2020, will legislation in a U.S. state allowing college athletes to receive financial compensation for their names, images, and/or likenesses become law?
preds: Several state legislatures have already put these to Governors for signature. will be lost on the fog of current events but signals the end of amateur athletics. High schools next?

SB 646 (Intercollegiate Athlete Compensation and Rights) was sent to Florida Governor Ron DeSantis.  He has 15 days to sign or veto the bill.  Governor DeSantis has expressed support for the bill.  I assume the governor will find time to make a decision on SB 646 during the COVID-19 pandemic. Source:
https://www.mysuncoast.com/2020/03/15/bill-that-would-allow-college-athletes-receive-pay-heading-desantis/
Colorado signed but it does not become law until 2023. With the GJ question requiring “become law” I revert back to 0% chance.
maintaining forecast. updating due to passage of time.
Decreasing probability based on states focusing on COVID-19 and the cancellation of most sporting events through the remainder of the survey period.
Passage of time. A lot if discussion but the country has other problems to solve.

I was not aware that there were multiple bills of this kind in the Florida House of Representatives and Senate (In my previous forecasts, I only mentioned HB 251). SB 646 passed the Florida House of Representatives and the Senate on March 13, 2020. It is now up to Governor DeSantis to sign the bill into law. The Florida legislature (House of Representatives and Senate) meets for 60 consecutive days each year. In even-numbered years (2020), the legislature convenes on the second Tuesday after the first Monday in January. For 2020, the legislature convened on January 14, 2020 and ended on March 13, 2020. Governor DeSantis has 15 days to sign the bill into law. The governor has expressed support for this kind of legislation. The coronavirus pandemic may take the governor's attention away from this legislation, but he has to make a decision within 15 days. Sources:
https://floridapolitics.com/archives/323384-legislature-passes-college-athlete-pay-bill See '19. What is the deadline for the Governor to sign a bill?': https://www.flsenate.gov/Reference/FAQ#Question19 Length of the session in the Florida Legislature: https://www.flsenate.gov/session 2020 session calendar: https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Calendar/2020/Session%20Dates%202020-01-20%20165718.PDF

Most likely in Florida - with 2 weeks to go for governor to sign it into law. https://www.statesman.com/sports/20200314/florida-legislators-send-college-athlete-name-image-and-likeness-bill-to-governor
Dropping forecast because everything is slowing down due to COVID19. Although amendments and bills have been passed in a few states in the past week, the path to becoming law is a much longer shot
Drastically dropping this forecast.  Due to Covid-19, there will be no rush to pass this law.
Covid-19. That will be the focus, and it's again unclear whether there's been any movement with (basically) two weeks to go.
The corona virus seems to be all consuming.
State legislatures will be distracted by corona virus beyond 1 April
Maybe California will rush through one positive change for good press in the midst of COVID stuff.

All the oxygen in the room is going to be sucked up by Covid-19, thus I can't imagine a situation in which a state takes time to pass this before the cut-off.  For the athlete's sake let's hope we cynics are wrong #paytheplayers.

Downgrading to "just barely above no-way, no-how". All states are going to be overwhelmed with Coronavirus response. No state is going to have the time or inclination to handle this kind of legislation in March 2020.
Looking at the track the world.is on with people's rights, it makes common sense that this law will be passed
FL, CT, NJ and KS are all circling closer to passing legislation.  Raising estimate, but still only 40 percent because the timing of when the states will pass legislation is still uncertain.
reducing forecast due to passage of time.

New update in NJ. The NJ bill has now cleared committee and now heads to the assembly speaker for consideration [1]. It is unclear how long that process will take, from the assembly speaker to law, but it seems unlikely to occur within a month. Correct me if I'm wildly wrong on that front.  [1] https://www.insidernj.com/press-release/swain-tully-wimberly-bill-allow-college-athletes-earn-endorsement-compensation-clears-committee/
From what I can tell there's been no movement towards making the thing happen since my last forecast (26/02), so I'm cutting down the probability by a few points.
Decreasing by 1%.  I don't see any movement on this question.

While I initially thought this was likely to happen- it's the first week of march and I'm not finding any data anywhere on discussions of this happening in the next 3 weeks. It seems states are more concerned with primaries and taking measures to prevent the spread of corona.  The NCAA has given them until January 2021 to create the rules.

The time I came to this question means there's barely a month, which means it'd probably be rushed if it did happen, and that would require a reason to rush which there isn't really. It seems like it's in the works in New Jersey or something, but I'm still not sure it's likely to get through.
Lowering as NJ bill continues to be stuck in committee
Decreasing by 1%.  I still don't see the bill on upcoming NJ agendas.

Changing my forecast to account for a revised assumption about the meaning of this question. Since CA's bill was signed by the Gov before 4 Oct, this question regards every state BUT CA. And, I will assume that a bill "becomes law" when it's signed by the state's executive. It seems NJ is moving along the quickest. But, given that the bill (971) still has several legal steps to go, is not even on the schedule for this week's business (see links in below conversation), and there are only 37 days left in this question, it seems very unlikely that NJ or any other state will sign a bill. Incentive-wise, given that the NCAA and the federal legislature have gotten involved, and given that NCAA legal team told the 9th Circuit Appeals court that they believe the CA law is unconstitutional, I'm guessing most other states will see state-level NIL initiatives as a waste of time they could be spending on other things.  The incentive for a state TO pass something in the next month or so would simply be to prevent CA from having an unfair advantage in this spring's recruiting season. So, there's a chance, but it's a very small one.

Based on the wide variety of estimates, I think there's some confusion about this question, particularly what it means for something to "become law". The CA law is already passed but won't take effect until 2023. Since this question is still open, I have to assume it will be resolved when a state's law actually "takes effect". Since even in CA that won't happen until 2023, there's no conceivable way any other state could pass a law and have it "take effect" in the next 40 days.  Unless I'm confused or just plain wrong, neither of which are impossible.

Increased slightly based on New Jersey's recent movement on legislation. However, the NCAA appears to be accepting California's law and has developed a timeline for each NCAA division to review implications and develop legislative proposals (for the NCAA, not states) to be voted on during next year's NCAA Convention (January 2021). With the NCAA taking proactive actions to implement the change, other states may be less inclined to develop their own legislative requirements. http://www.ncaa.org/about/taking-action

Decreasing by 1%.  This question is hinged on New Jersey.  The bill passed the Senate and is now with the Assembly Higher Education Committee.  I just checked the legislative calendar and don't see the bill on the agenda for any session over the next week.  It seems that the bill will make it through the Assembly given bi-partisan support, but I'm not sure how long it will take.  Additionally, I do not know how long it typically takes before the Governor will sign it. https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/legislativepub/calendar/021420.htm
Other states will have to do this unless they want their NCAA teams to begin losing out to California teams.

New Jersey introduced bill S971 in their legislature (specifically the Senate) on January 27, 2020.  The bill passed the Senate on February 10, 2020.  The bill was received by the Assembly on February 13, 2020 and was referred to the Assembly's Higher Education Committee on the same day.  If your look at New Jersey's legislative calendar (which runs from February 19, 2020 to March 26, 2020), S971 is not listed.  I don't know how the legislative process works in New Jersey, but I would be surprised if the bill passed before or by April 1, 2020. Status of S971 in the New Jersey legislature: https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp?BillNumber=S971 New Jersey legislative calendar: https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/legislativepub/calendar/021420.htm
Increasing estimate slightly due to progress in NJ. https://www.tapinto.net/towns/nutley/sections/government/articles/nj-state-senate-passes-new-jersey-fair-play-act-5

Great analysis by @DukeNuke, but to echo @RabbottAbbott11, it looks like New Jersey passed the bill through the Senate but still needs to get through the House and the Governor.  The bill was introduced to the Senate on 27 Jan and passed on 10 Feb.  I'm not sure though if that timeline is similar for the House and the Governor, but I'm skeptical.  Of all the states with proposals, NJ seems to be the closest; however, I'm decreasing my forecast by 3% due to this question most likely hinging on one state pushing the bill through in roughly 6 weeks. Info on the NJ bill can be found at https://www.njleg.state.nj.us by searching "971". https://www.phillytrib.com/news/state_and_region/n-j-senate-approves-legislation-allowing-college-athletes-to-earn/article_e3473a66-3ee5-57b4-82c0-130108e040d7.html

Increasing due to New Jersey's efforts. Senate Bill 971 was passed through the Senate on 2/10/2020 with a vote of 21-10 (8 not voting). It must now pass through the House, then be signed by the Governor. Still a lot of work to be done, but it is getting closer to becoming law in NJ. Source: https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/bills/BillView.asp

Terrific research into each state's efforts by DukeNuke below. After reviewing the links for the various bills, I concur that the odds are extremely low that any state would be able to pass a law (this excludes the CA bill, which precedes this question's time frame) in the next 46 days. However, another contributor pointed out that there is a very strong incentive for other states to pass something this spring so CA doesn't end up with a significant recruiting advantage (even though their law won't take effect until 1 Jan 2023). It seems clear also that federal legislation will be required, but that will be many months, if not years, from now at best. So, the most likely scenario is that a state passes something simple (or maybe even symbolic) that meets the threshold of this question for the purpose of competing against CA.

New Jersey Fair Play Act passes General Assembly in December https://www.insidernj.com/press-release/new-jersey-fair-play-act-measures-banning-smoking-airport-pickup-areas-establishing-regional-health-hub-program-thursday-assembly-panel-agendas/ It passed the Senate earlier today https://www.tapinto.net/towns/nutley/sections/government/articles/nj-state-senate-passes-new-jersey-fair-play-act-5 Next stop is the governors desk. Scope has now become an increasingly important factor. I couldn’t find info on when the bill is headed to his desk or if he’ll sign it. The proposal enjoys bipartisan support, so I imagine that elevates the probability. Newsom only took 19 days to sign. Bumping up to 75% in light of new information

At the moment, the states of Colorado, Florida, Illinois, Kentucky, Maryland, Minnesota, Nevada, New York, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Washington have all introduced or a considering legislation allowing college athletes to receive financial compensation for their name and/or image.  So far, the states that have introduced legislation in their state houses and/or senate are Florida, Illinois, New York and Washington. Florida
HB 251 was introduced in the Florida House of Representatives on September 30, 2019.  It went through its first reading on January 14, 2020.  HB 251 has not reached the Florida Senate yet. Status of HB 251 in the Florida House of Representatives: https://www.myfloridahouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=66760 Status of HB 251 in the Florida Senate: https://www.flsenate.gov/Session/Bill/2020/251/?Tab=BillHistory Illinois
HB3904 was introduced in the Illinois General Assembly on September 30, 2019.  The bill passed all readings in the House of Representatives and arrived in the Senate on October 30, 2019 where it held its first reading.  The bill was referred to assignments (pursuant to Senate Rule 3-9(b)) on December 15, 2019.  Since then, it appears that there hasn't been any movement on the bill. Satus of HB3904 in the Illinois General Assembly (House of Representatives and Senate): http://ilga.gov/legislation/billstatus.asp?DocNum=3904&GAID=15&GA=101&DocTypeID=HB&LegID=122043&SessionID=108 New York
It appears that S6722B was introduced in the State Assembly in September 2019..  The bill was referred to the Higher Education committee on January 8, 2020.  So far, the bill is still in committee. Status of S6722B in the New York State Assembly: https://nyassembly.gov/leg/?default_fld=&leg_video=&bn=S06722&term=2019&Summary=Y&Actions=Y&Committee%26nbspVotes=Y&Floor%26nbspVotes=Y Status of S6722B in New York Senate: https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/bills/2019/s6722 Washington
HB 1084 was first introduced in the State Assembly in January 2019.  At the time, the bill did not pass.  It was re-introduced in the State Assembly on January 13, 2020.  So far, the bill has only been introduced and executive action was taken on the bill in the House Committee on College and Workforce Development on February 4, 2020.  It has not been introduced in the Senate yet. Status of HB 1084 in the Washington State Assembly: https://app.leg.wa.gov/billsummary?BillNumber=1084&Year=2019&Initiative=false I am not familiar with the legislative process and session of state legislatures.  Given the current status of the bills, there doesn't seem to be enough time for any of those bills to pass within the give time range (October 4, 2019 to April 1, 2020).

Issue is important.  As written CA passed such as law before the Oct 2019 to April 1, 2020 period.  CA is a big dog and I have to believe at least one of the other 49 states will follow their lead.  Who want to risk the disadvantage in recruiting.
The California law appears to be somewhat controversial, so other states will probably wait.  http://www.ncaa.org/questions-and-answers-name-image-and-likeness
Impeachment and election are distracting many lawmakers.

basing my forecast on likelihood of state legislatures meeting in time to consider and pass legislation.  New York legislation seems to be most progressive and is still in committee at this time.  Would have to pass floor debate, and senate and assembly before becoming law which appears to me to be unlikely at this point.  Additionally, NCAA Federal and State legislative committee is still gathering information and working through a April 2020 deadline for a follow up recommendation but NCAA is against separate state bills and will push back against state efforts to legislate, in favor of a national law consistent across all states.  Will monitor NY bill and update accordingly.

The NCAA is crafting rules due in 2021. California has passed legislation but I think given the controversial nature of this states will wait and or negotiate with the NCAA before they pass anything. https://fortune.com/2019/10/30/ncaa-decision-college-athletes-pay/
Too early and not enough time, it is a matter of time that the hypocrisy of the issue becomes recognized, thus there would be no more hypocrites!

The California "Fair Pay to Play" Act was introduced on 4 February 2019 and not signed into law until 30 September 2019. Given the almost eight month processing time, it's unlikely that other states with proposed legislation will be able to process their bills any faster. The states most likely to pass the law within this timeframe would be Florida (introduced 30 September 2019; first reading occurred on 14 January 2020) and Illinois (introduced 30 September 2019; passed House vote on 30 October 2019; last action in Senate on 15 December 2019 to refer to Assignments). A key determinant for other states may be how the NCAA responds to California's legislation.  The 2020 NCAA Convention is currently underway in Anaheim, CA where two statements have already been issued on the topic:
http://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/statement-federal-and-state-legislation-working-group-co-chairs-name-image-and-likeness-efforts
http://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/di-board-presidential-forum-discuss-name-image-and-likeness-issues
Additionally, the 9th Circuit Court has already asked the NCAA and Athletes to provide comment on how this legislation affects an already underway anti-trust suit related to student-athlete compensation.

Given the precedent that CA set and the NCAA board of governors vote to allow it, it seems likely (>50%) that another state will pass legislation aside from CA.  Unfortunately, I'm unable to set a clear base rate, other than assessing that when one state has set a precedent and the governing body has expressed support that the chances for success are more positive than negative.  The question is whether it will happen by 1 Apr in the at least 10 states who have bills in progress.  I intend to research the status in each state but am placing my initial forecast at 63% due to the number of states trying to pass the legislation.  The lack of urgency to pass the bill as soon as possible gives me pause in starting with a higher initial forecast.
Tweaking forecast down a bit. I haven't seen any activity lately.

FL rep Kione McGee introduced the bill as HB 25 last week.
Effective date of 7-1-2020
It seems to be referred to committee per the designation "HJ 25" - but I don't see which House committee has it.
In any event - in spot-reviewing the life cycle of 2019 bills that were enacted into law - it looks like it takes 6 months from filing to signing on something that has no real opposition (ex: HB 87: Registering and Titling of Vehicles and Vessels)
A lot of bills die in committee(s)
I don't know the degree of opposition in FL - but it is of a matter that I would think requires reflection and debate----and thus time.
So to get this done in under 90 days seems implausible.

I hope so.  We are not jocks so I never considered the time, practice, diet and focus it takes to reach the college level.  Then you blow out your knee and you lost your scholarship and your body is forever less. Already enacted in California others will follow

dramatic (almost embarrassing) size of NCAA and collegiate profits from basketball and football programs  (TV and endorsements), will shock and then motivate public support for athlete compensation packages (which is easy to figure, a percent of NCAA profits go into a fund, when athlete leaves school she gets a check).
College players are now pros playing for room and board.

When a college or a company uses you name or you as a selling point as the do advertising a game on TV.  That person should receive a royalty. It is their talent that is placing the college in the bowl game. Making the student responsible for all the money received by the college.

It's challenging to find a clear analog to this situation, despite the fact that CA is known for passing trend-setting legislation that has been discussed but not addressed at the federal level. Perhaps medical and then recreational marijuana share some similarities, in as much as they were long discussed and debated before one state made a move that appeared to create a cascade effect. While recreational marijuana shares some of the competitive incentives that characterize "fair pay to play;" unfortunately, WA and CO adopted their measures through ballot initiatives, so the potential analogy breaks down. That said, the information available on efforts in FL, NY, PA, and IL suggests adoption in one or more of these states by 1 April is possible, with the pre-April 1 end of FL's session particularly interesting. CO could be a dark horse, as similar legislation was introduced at the end of its last legislative session, and is expected to be reintroduced now that its 2020 session has begun. The fact that some states perceive that they could be at a competitive disadvantage if they do not pass legislation allowing college athletes to be compensated before the end of their 2020 legislative session, and prior to the next recruiting seasons, pushes my estimate a little higher.

Similar legislation is being discussed in at least 20 other states (https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/colleges/the-ncaa-is-still-whining-about-pay-to-play-its-too-late-for-that/2019/10/16/d128a2c8-f01e-11e9-8693-f487e46784aa_story.html), but these types of laws don't seem to become official very quickly. Thus, I think this is very likely to become the law in many states, but the timeline might be longer than the 1 April 2020 deadline of this question. It is also unclear that NCAA will change their rules that quickly, although they probably will before the CA legislation goes into effect in 2023).

NCAA is supporting CA ruling, but it will take some time (years) to go into effect.  There is little incentive for other states to add legislation prior to NCAA  rule changes when it is clear it will do so.
Timing will be difficult despite new California legislation

NCAA working on rules after okaying this. States might hold up until those rules are out. http://www.pewtrusts.org/research-and-analysis/blogs/stateline/2019/04/26/these-state-lawmakers-want-college-athletes-to-get-paid

Despite many bills being introduced, the 1 April deadline does not leave a lot of time for the legislative process to work.   From @tuzlarob:
According to the Florida house website, the Florida House Bill 251 was referred to 3 separate committees on 10 October 2019 and has not progressed since that time. Three other related bills (S 582, H287, and S646) were also referred to committee between 16 October and 6 November. Two bills (1 house, 1 senate) are sponsored by democrats and 2 bills (1 house, 1 senate) are sponsored by Republicans. Both parties have sponsored bills which seek an effective date in 2020. The session ends on 13 March 2020.
crowd forecast, need to do more research.

A brand-new state (Oklahoma) has just had a bill introduced, and a new nationwide poll showing 66% support for this issue has just come out:
https://www.courant.com/sports/college/hc-sp-ncaa-athletes-endorsements-poll-20200106-20200106-k4mkpovh6zfytetsqprmp5lxjq-story.html

State legislative processes simply take a long time, so 90 days seems too soon.
Kudos to @Tuzlarob for some research that made me reconsider the speed of such an effort.
Updating based on written contributions from several forecasters.
inertia is a real bump in the road when dealing with state institutions cautiously trying to make sure they monetize it in a way most favorable to the Universities.

California's bill already became law in 2019, but did so outside of the window specified in the question.  According to multiple sites, the NCAA's board of governors voted on 29 October to allow college athletes to be compensated for the use of the name, image, and likeness (NIL).  Several states have bills drafted and at various stages of drafting or approval including: Florida, New York, Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Washington, Maryland, Connecticut, and South Carolina.  I have outlined the status of a few known bills at the state level based on an article from CBS sports journalist Matt Norlander.   According to the NY Senate website, Senate bill S6722B is in the Senate Rules committee as of 2 January 2020.  An Assembly bill A8620 was introduced in October and remains in the higher education committee as of 2 Jan.  This law goes beyond just NIL rights and extends to a form of revenue sharing.  To become law, the bill still needs to pass through committee, be scheduled for debate on the floor, pass both the assembly and the Senate and then signed by the Governor.  Unlike the California bill, the NY bill does not have bipartisan sponsorship.  The breadth of sponsorship is less of a factor for passage since the Democratic party has a majority in both chambers, however, it may slow down the proceedings. The New York legislature will be in session for only 38 days between now and 1 April.  The schedule for the bill's next steps are unclear - no known scheduled meetings or hearings.  Due to the expanded scope of this bill and the deadline for the question, it is unlikely this bill will pass in the time allotted.   The Illinois bill (HB3904) has passed the house, and moved into the senate in November of last year.  The bill is currently assigned to a subcommittee in the senate.  The bill is the only one assigned to the Subcommittee.  The bill has broad, though largely partisan, sponsorship.  The Illinois legislature will only be in session for 23 days prior to 1 April and has a deadline of 27 March for substantive bills to leave committee.  Though this bill seems to be making steady progress, the spring schedule appears to leave little time for the passage and signature into law prior to 1 April.   Washington state had a bill introduced at the beginning of 2019, but the bill does not appear to have moved since that time.   According to the Florida house website, the Florida House Bill 251 was referred to 3 separate committees on 10 October 2019 and has not progressed since that time.  Three other related bills (S 582, H287, and S646) were also referred to committee between 16 October and 6 November.  Two bills (1 house, 1 senate) are sponsored by democrats and 2 bills (1 house, 1 senate) are sponsored by Republicans.  Both parties have sponsored bills which seek an effective date in 2020.    The session ends on 13 March 2020.  It is likely FL will pass the bill and have it signed into law prior to 1 April.   I highly recommend the website legiscan.com for research on legislative affairs at the state level.  It provides a good starting place if you have only basic details.

Half the state legislatures are working on it now. Just one example:
https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/bills/2019/s6722
So, with 25 states in various phases of such a law, if there is a 2% chance that any given one gets the bill into law by April 1st, that means a 60% chance. (To do the math, take .98 to the 25th power and then subtract that from 1.)  Add in Washington, DC, and that gets us to 62%.
NCAA will have to react anyway. There ist no real need to build up more pressure. But some politicians might want to use the issue to get (re-) elected.

https://www.ajc.com/blog/politics/paying-the-worker-bees-billion-year-college-athletic-machine/rACz4TWm8L2s3zCTHMoV0N/ " . . . Georgia’s soon-to-be senior senator has joined a bipartisan working group attempting to deal with the implications of a suddenly viral concept that burst from the West Coast only three months ago: That athletes should get a piece of the $14 billion in annual revenue that colleges and universities collect courtesy of their sweat and pain. . . . similar efforts [to California's] in 20 or more states have jumped up, blurring the political line that separates red and blue. In Georgia, state Rep. Billy Mitchell, D-Stone Mountain, says that by the time the Legislature convenes in January, his measure, House Bill 743, will have more Republican signatures than Democratic ones.Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, has endorsed like-minded legislation.“So here we go,” Perdue said in a phone interview. “We’re going to have an arms race between states about recruiting high school kids for college sports. That’s a problem. All of a sudden now, we need a level playing field. .  . .  In October, Romney issued a warning to the NCAA, which has long balked at loosening rules on athlete compensation.“We’re coming for you,” Romney said. “We’re coming to help these young athletes in the future, and the athletes of today, make sure that they don’t have to sacrifice their time and sacrifice, in many cases, their bodies without being fairly compensated.”
. . . 
. . .  A 2017 poll by the Washington Post found that 54% of African-Americans support paying college athletes, but only 31% of whites felt the same. There was broader consensus – 89% among blacks, 60% among whites — on permitting players to earn money if their name or image is used on merchandise.This is where most legislation, state and federal, appears to be headed. “That’s the easiest to get at first. It’s not the only issue,” Perdue said.But even that has complications. Consider the fleet-footed star running back and the anonymous lineman who plows the field ahead of him. “How do you allow a kid to get paid signing jerseys with his name on the back? And then, how do you split that with the other players on the team, and the university?” Perdue asked.Or should you? There is a labor-versus-management aspect to the issue of athletic pay. Booker and most other Democratic presidential candidates have endorsed allowing athletes to earn money from their names and images. Sens. Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts support allowing players to unionize as well.Others, and Perdue is among them, emphasize the preservation of college sports as an institution in a shifting landscape.“My concern is that we don’t have agents sitting in kitchens signing contracts with high school kids and negotiating contracts – instead of being recruited by colleges, destroying the student athlete,” he said.Five years ago, the NCAA benched star UGA tailback Todd Gurley for four games — for accepting money from autograph dealers. The Legislature quickly passed, and the governor signed into law, a measure aimed at those who tempt college athletes into risking their amateur status. The penalty: Jail time and a fine of up to $25,000.Those days appear to be on the edge of extinction.In late October, meeting on the campus of Emory University, the NCAA’s top governing body voted unanimously to allow athletes to be paid for use of their name, image and likeness “in a manner consistent with the collegiate model.”What that collegiate model is has yet to be defined. Perdue said the NCAA is expected to come up with preliminary rules in January, with a final decision coming in April. The Power Five conferences, the SEC among them, are working on the issue as well.The senator hopes the two groups can come up with a solution that will pass muster with Congress. Lord knows, every sports bar in Georgia will be watching.
~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This question asks about STATE legislation, not Federal or NCAA.  I wonder if state legislation may get co-opted by federal or NCAA actions???

With California leading the way there's going to be other states willing to try like Washington or Colorado. With legalizing fiscal expenditures there's increased opportunity for players and state collegiate growth - all donors to politicians. With increasing collegiate programs taking in millions from ticket, merchandise, and donations, there's substantial fiscal reason to push legislation through in areas where colleges are on the verge of breaking in to mainstream adoption. By enabling fiscal compensation future year athletes will have renewed reasons to compete and declare their University of choice. With all those reasons there's still lingering governmental timelines to consider which weigh on the likelihood.
I wish it was higher, but there will be resistance, and Legislation sometimes Needs Long time to do ist work.
Could see Oregon and/or Washington state following California's lead on this.

there are a few states where this is already in the hopper...election coming up...state legislative sessions tend to be in the early calendar year...beating up on the NCAA is pretty much the easiest political points on the board right now--really...what other issue passes the California legislative process with near unanimous bipartisian support???  Yet politics is messy and there really isn't that long until April, politically speaking.

Interesting read on the “race to the bottom” California’s bill has created. Seems like New York is the most likely state to act next, followed by Florida and Illinois. Nine states have proposed legislation that is similar to California's.  Illinois has a bill that has strong support that will be introduced in Oct and could be passed as early as Jan 1, 2020. Eight other states, several of them with full time legislatures have also proposed bills that could be signed into law soon, most notably New York.  The bill has strong support there as well and has to potential to be passed spring of 2020.  All bills, if signed into law, would take effect in 2023.  With CA leading the way, other states are going to scramble quickly to ensure they can use this as a recruiting tool.

California passed unanimously (Democrats and Republicans) a law allowing student athletes to receive financial compensation for their names, images, and/or likenesses.  The legislation is to take place in 2023.  The long delay for the law to go into effect is due to the expected lawsuits from NCAA and other schools.  Indeed, NCAA threatens to ban CA schools from participation in NCAA sports if the law goes into effect.  The law is also a way to prod NCAA into reforms. In fact, after the legislation was introduced in February, NCAA formed a working group to look into the matter.  Its final report is due in October [1]. There is no question a school allowing student athletes to receive financial compensation for their names will have a big advantage in recruiting athletes.  Will other states join the bandwagon?  I suspect not within the time frame of this forecast.  One reason is that the CA law does not come into effect until 2023 – there is no need to hurry.  The second reason is that NCAA might change the rule after its committee studied the issue.  If so, there is no need for other states to pass legislation for it. Furthermore, allowing student athletes to receive financial compensation for their names is a low bar compared with paying athletes.  It does not cost the schools (and NCAA) much, if any.  Therefore it is relatively easy for NCAA to change its rule on this.  If NCAA changes the rule allowing this, no school gains advantage or loses disadvantage.  While NCAA wants to maintain the facade of amateurism in its multi-million business, I suspect it will reform on this issue.   I liken this to the collapse of amateurism in the Olympics. There is a chance of one or two states that join the bandwagon.  The probability is 2/50 = 4%. [1]  http://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/media-center/news/ncaa-working-group-examine-name-image-and-likeness
11 States now proposing similar legislation.  FL, IL, NY appear the most aggressive.

A factor that I haven't seen in comments below is that basketball's final signing day is May 20th, 2020, football is April 1, 2020. When the law is passed is going to determine which recruiting cycle it affects. Football has a bunch of money, but basketball players could be more likely to get a big early endorsement. Especially with the one and done rule. Schools will also be considering if only a few states initially pass the law (even if it is after April) it will likely also have a significant impact on transfers. 
Next factor for me is can the legislation be passed that quickly (when that much money is involved, probably yes) mixed with how much they want it to factor into this recruiting cycle.
Followed by what is the NCAA going to say in their meeting at the end of the month.  http://www.nationalletter.org/signingDates/index.html

As a results, that would require a base rate of <50%. https://www.quora.com/How-long-does-it-take-to-pass-a-bill-in-the-US/ California’s law took 8 months to pass, so I’d adjust down further.  Multiple states are currently considering laws, but there are only 5 bills in 4 states (Florida has two) that have actually been submitted (https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cbssports.com/college-football/news/fair-pay-to-play-act-states-bucking-ncaa-to-let-athletes-be-paid-for-name-image-likeness/amp/) Scope seems to be the major risk to this question.  There is a NCAA meeting in which this will be discussed at the end of the month. Failure to act on the part of the NCAA could drive more legislation, but a promise to examine the issue further may make legislatures pause.  I’ll size the odds of the NCAA saying something of substance at 70%. If this happens, I see a 65% chance that legislatures pause. If the NCAA says nothing or doubles down on amateurism (30%), I see an 75% chance of a Bill being fast-tracked. This would put me at a 45% chance of a Bill being passed.  Time-frame and scope would make me adjust down, but even if each of the 5 bills has a 10% chance of passing before April, that is a 50% that at least one will pass. Going to split the difference: 47% Will update on Oct 27 based on responses to the NCAA working group
NC, SC also in the mix.

California is arguably more important to the NCAA and its constituent conferences than vice versa, so the latter will not likely follow through on the threat to disqualify California schools from the Official Competitions.  The same, arguably, goes for Texas and Florida and several other states with very large collegiate sports audiences.   Also, if compensation gives permitting states a recruiting advantage, which might reasonably be expected, other states are likely to fall in line as briskly as they can arrange to. However, legislative calendars are not likely to be seismically reshuffled to accommodate this legislation, and time is short in Legislature World.  Coming up a bit, but not much. Fun, if that's the word, fact:  In a very large proportion of US states, the highest paid public employee is the state u's gridiron football coach.

https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/464268-california-inspires-other-states-to-push-to-pay-college-athletes "A new California law that will allow collegiate athletes to profit from the use of their name or images has fueled a rush of new legislation in other states that hope to allow their own athletes to make money while still in college.
. . . 
The new bills are coming from both Democratic and Republican sponsors, marking a rare bipartisan moment that legislators across the country said would go a long way to addressing inequality and even racial injustice in sports. “It is pretty strange to be citing California for anything. But it is a kind of beautifully bipartisan issue, because you have injustices, especially racial injustice,” said Nolan West, a Republican state representative in Minnesota who plans to introduce his own version of the bill next year.
. . . 
Florida state Rep. Kionne McGhee, the Democratic minority leader who represents part of Miami-Dade County, is driving a similar bill in Tallahassee.
. . . 
Similar legislation has been introduced in Washington, Maryland and New York. South Carolina lawmakers said they would introduce a bill like California’s version next year. Legislators in Tennessee have filed a bill to create a fund to compensate college athletes after they graduate.
. . . 
. . . in a letter to Newsom last month, the NCAA threatened what could become a legal showdown. It said the NCAA could declare California schools ineligible for its events, because giving players the right to earn money from endorsement deals would give California schools an unfair recruiting advantage. Despite the threat, the California legislature passed its bill unanimously. Newsom signed the legislation earlier this week alongside one of its most prominent backers, LeBron James. In a statement Monday, the PAC-12 Conference said the legislation would “have very significant negative consequences for our student-athletes and broader universities in California.”
. . . 
Opponents say the new laws would cause damage to the current system, which provides scholarships and even spending money to thousands of student athletes across the country.
. . . 
But West, the Minnesota Republican, said paying athletes would both broaden the number of people who benefit from their talent during their college years, and incentivize more players to stay in school to actually earn their degree.  “A lot of high school stars, like king of the town who just tears it up, will never make it to the NFL,” West said. “The super good players who are real prospects for the professional leagues now do have an incentive to stay in school and get their degrees.” The NCAA has been under mounting pressure to spread its wealth around, as college athletics have become a $14 billion a year industry. Thirty-eight schools around the country generate more than $100 million in sports revenue annually, according to data compiled by USA Today. The NCAA itself generated more than $1 billion in revenue for the first time in 2017. But, seemingly aware that the dam was about to break, the NCAA earlier this year set up a working group to study potential changes to rules governing student athlete endorsement deals. That working group plans to finish its report by the end of October. After that report comes out, federal legislation is likely. Rep. Anthony Gonzalez (R-Ohio), a standout wide receiver at Ohio State who went on to play for the Indianapolis Colts, plans to introduce a bill once he sees recommendations from the committee. Gonzalez is close with Ohio State athletic director Gene Smith, the committee’s co-chairman. In March, Rep. Mark Walker (R-N.C.) has introduced his own legislation similar to the California measure. Walker’s Student-Athlete Equity Act has yet to receive a hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee."

Sports Illustrated is tracking the variety of bills related to this question. [1] They suggest that about 9 states are considering laws on these issues. A few have been filed, but most are still in earlier stages of the legislative process. Politically, these bills do not seem to controversial  (both Republicans and Democrats supported them in California). So, the main problem here is whether these bills can go through the legislative pipeline fast enough. In addition, it's unclear to me what incentives are for other states to pass these bills. On one hand the NCAA is not a powerful lobbyist at the state level, but I don't think there is great political gain in passing any of these bills. Similarly, I don't think there is any urgency for policy makers on these questions. I doubt any will get through in this 6 month period, but in a year or two I would assign a much higher probability. 

[1] https://www.si.com/college-football/2019/10/02/tracking-ncaa-fair-play-image-likeness-laws

Irrespective of the merits on this issue, the calendar is working against such a bill, which is certain to be controversial for reasons both good and the other thing.   Between now and 1 April is not a time when most legislatures get anything complicated done.  Many are already out of session, not to return until after the first of the year, and those that are still in are up against budget deadlines or are otherwise exhausted.  The same, mutatis mutandis, will be true of those returning in January.    Such bills will doubtless be introduced in a number of states, but they will languish in committee until safely after 1 April.  A deadline of, say, 10 June would have made this a closer bet.  (Full disclosure: I have not worked with US state legislatures extensively in a couple of decades, so they may have changed their ways.  Anybody got a line on this?)
Its time for the NCAA to come clean and regents to just be upfront about it,
